Award.AwardTitle: Bayesian Decision Theoretic Methods for Some High-Dimensional Multiple Inference Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project covers some outstanding and important inference problems that statisticians face when analyzing high-dimensional data from brain imaging, next generation sequencing, atmospheric science, astronomical studies, and many other scientific investigations. Miss-detecting a strong signal in these experiments, particularly when the signals are sparse, is often a more severe error than miss-detecting a weak signal, and this error gets more severe as the signal gets stronger. This is an important issue which has not been fully utilized in the existing procedures designed for simultaneous testing of multiple hypotheses. Also, selective inference using multiple confidence intervals is an emerging area of statistical research whose importance is being realized very recently. However, while analyzing high-dimensional data with sparse signals, the existing intervals designed to provide estimates of the selected significant signals can become non-informative in the sense of miss-covering the true signal or covering zero too often if the sparse nature of the data is not properly taken into account. This research project seeks to develop new and innovative methods taking a Bayesian decision theoretic viewpoint which is particularly well suited to tackle these issues. It focuses on the following two broad areas of research: (i) Developing new multiple testing methods controlling false discoveries incorporating the severity of type II errors, and (ii) developing new multiple confidence intervals for selected parameters under zero-inflated mixture prior.

This project will be expected to have a broad impact on the theory and practice of statistics. It can produce novel methodologies to detect true signals in modern and high-dimensional scientific investigations, and pave the way for better use of statistics towards meeting modern societal and scientific needs. For instance, understanding vegetation changes under seasonal variability is crucial for more effective land use management when coping with climate changes and food security. This project can potentially offer new methodologies towards addressing that sustainability issue. Also, there is an increasing demand for sophisticated statistical tools to have better understanding of astronomical behaviors based on the influx of data created by the advent of new technologies. Again, this project can potentially meet that demand. The results will be disseminated through presentations and discussions at national and international conferences, and visits to other institutions. The software to be developed under this project will be made available, free of charge, to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Big Data analysis has been one of the most popular words to the general public in the last five years since President Obama's data-driven re-election campaign. It has reshaped our daily life, such as our shopping habits, recreational styles, and many others. Big Data also arises in different aspects of the scientific research, such as those in medicines, genomics, astronomy, atmospheric science, drug discovery, and many others. As data can now be easily accumulated to a level that is beyond the human's imagination, there is still a need for developing newer, more efficient, faster, and more reliable methodologies for analyzing data sets. Motivated by that need, the PI, co-PI, and their students and collaborators have developed novel methods for answering real scientific problems and provided related software for public usage with the support of the current grant.


The outcome of this grant consists of two parts, (i) theoretical and methodological developments, advancing the knowledge and understanding of the importance of statistical tools in Big Data analysis, and (ii) applications of the developed methods to real data, which have been disseminated to scientists, governments, medical researchers, and drug developers through peer-reviewed publications and presentations at conferences and academic institutes. 

One of the main contributions of theoretical research undertaken in this project has been to study the issue of "Selection Bias", or "Winner's Curse", which refers to a phenomenon in common value auctions when the winner of an auction usually overpays the auctioned asset. This occurs often in many scientific studies as well, especially in the context of Big Data. For instance, the contribution of a particular gene to a certain disease can be exaggerated in a statistical process of selecting it. Similarly, in studies involving large number of features, the effect of a winning feature is usually over-estimated. Therefore, it is important to remove selection bias while developing inferential methods. The PI and his collaborators have successfully utilized empirical Bayes approach to tackle this issue in the context of hypothesis testing and reported the results in two refereed publications and one completed manuscript.

The second main contribution is the development of optimal multiple testing procedures for high-dimensional data analysis using a decision theoretic approach. Because of its importance in modern scientific investigations, the field of multiple testing has gained tremendous attention in the last two decades, and a number of methods have been proposed in the literature from different viewpoints. Nevertheless, there are some fundamentally important issues that are yet to be fully addressed. For instance, (i) the traditional testing methods aiming to discover signals completely ignore the severity of missing a true signal with a large effect size; (ii) the dependence among hypotheses and the corresponding test statistics are usually ignored; and (iii) the underlying hypotheses are often seen to be grouped but it is mostly ignored due to technical difficulties. Supported by the current grant, the PI and his collaborators have proposed novel methods addressing these issues and have published three papers and written five more manuscripts.

The PI also devoted much of his time and effort to solve challenging scientific questions arising in Big Data analysis.
